recordings.loc: Baywood-Los Osos, San Luis Obispo County, California
recordings.rmk: I’m zeroing in on Downy Woodpecker. The average cadence is 15.6 beats/second, and it averages 20.5 beats/bout. From what I’ve read, Downy drums at 15.8 beats/sec, Nuttall’s at about 20.8, Northern Flicker at 19.3 and Hairy at 26.6.

recordings.rmk: not seen actually drumming; two individuals seen in the area after the fact, one of which was weakly responsive to playback of the drum (all recordings natural), but Hairy and N Flicker also seen; drum speed is typical of Downy (slow, 16/sec); in burn area near Akers Lake; intervals shortened at 1:54 and 2:42; recordings over a 12-minute period; date stamp wrong about year;

recordings.loc: Swan Lake, Victoria, Vancouver Island, BC
recordings.rmk: Drumming from female Downy Woodpecker while searching for food on diseased tree in flooded woodlands on southern side of Swan Lake.  Flew to tree and spent about 10 minutes moving up the tree and drumming.  When an insect is found, it pecks away the bark and feeds. Partially cloudy day,  about 3 C, with snow on ground and mainly frozen ponds and lake.

recordings.rmk: At first I assumed this was a squirrel, but then a male Downy Woodpecker flew in with an insect in his bill. I did not see him flying to, nor did I see, the nest hole. To "tell the story" I added the sound of this male flying away,  at the end of the begging calls (1:21.0 ).  I recorded it hoping the male would call, but he was silent. Riparian habitat in mostly dry river bed with Cottonwood, Walnut trees, willow thickets, adjacent to oak savannah. (Sennheiser ME62 omni mic, 24 inch Roché parabola, Marantz PMD 661).

recordings.loc: Bloomingdale, Chatham County, Georgia
recordings.rmk:
I originally posted this file as Hairy Woodpecker, a species not yet verifiably identified in this coastal county.  After creating a spectrogram of my recording and comparing it to those of Hairy and Downy I created from Cornell I concluded Downy.
 
I heard two birds calling and saw them land in clear woodpecker fashion on the limbs of a dead snag, in a pine tree, vocalizing all the while. Although my original intent in exploring this new area was to find Hairy Woodpecker, I was there recording frogs this morning. As a result I was able to turn the microphone on the pair and get about one minute of vocalization. Photography was not possible with poor lighting and distance.

I used a Sound Devices 722 with a Sennheiser ME67 long shotgun microphone. The file as been altered for clarity, including increasing gain to -06 from the original -16, deleting human artifacts, and employing a conservative high pass filter, and equally conservative noise reduction in Audacity to diminish ambient distractions. The cadence of vocalizations is largely untouched. The original WAV file is available.

recordings.loc: Oxford, Lafayette County, Mississippi
recordings.rmk:
Foraging on the smaller outer limbs of a large water oak (*Quercus nigra*). Distance from microphone variable 5-10m.

#Habitat#
State waterfowl refuge along the margins of USACE flood control reservoir. Strip along the lake margins ~1km wide of moist soil grassland with mix of forbs, native warm season grasses (Andropogon, Schyzachyrium, Eragrostis, Aristida, etc.), and some sparse woody vegetation (Cephalanthus, Quercus saplings, etc.) bounded by oak hickory forest and, in places, pine plantation.  Three or four shallow waterfowl impoundments partially flooded in the winter.

#Editing#
Edited in Adobe Audition. Butterworth high-pass filter, order 3, cutoff frequency 700 Hz. 

#Equipment#
Fostex FR-2 digital recorder with Sennheiser microphone and Telinga pro 22" parabolic reflector.

recordings.loc: Mendota, Fresno County, California
recordings.rmk:
This 1+ minute recording documents at least one juvenile Downy Woodpecker calling almost continuously from within a cavity in a tree willow. This recording also documents an adult female Downy Woodpecker that had just delivered food to the nestling inside. She was alarmed by my presence and called quite vociferously.

<http://ebird.org/ebird/view/checklist?subID=S23667464>

recordings.loc: Mendota, Fresno County, California
recordings.rmk:
This 5+ minute recording documents at least one juvenile Downy Woodpecker calling almost continuously from within a cavity in a tree willow. Toward the end of the recording, an adult female Downy Woodpecker visits the hole entrance to deliver food. Shortly after the recording ended an adult male Downy Woodpecker made a food delivery as well.

This recording was made with an iPhone 5s with Sennheiser shotgun microphone and the Røde Rec application. This recording has not been modified in any manner. There is some narration by the recordist.

For further details see: http://ebird.org/ebird/view/checklist?subID=S23667464

recordings.loc: Dunncroft/Castle Point Park, Glen Allen, VA
recordings.rmk:
The park is a mixed pine/deciduous forest with creeks running through it.  The weather was in the upper 60's, sunny, no wind.

I heard the call first and searched for the bird because it was such an unusual vocalization.  I followed it from tree to tree until I could get a decent shot with my camera.  It was high in a pine tree.  There was no unusual behavior for a Downy Woodpecker.  

The recording has not been altered in anyway except being saved as an .mp3.
